turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Are you saying that he's...

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: Shhhhhh.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Mother o'god...

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: Give the man a hug, boy!  That's your father!

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Tomorrow afternoon...  ... oh my god...

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: Exactly.  Break it to her gently.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: You ever been in this town before, to your knowledge?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: No.  But...

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: But what?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Well, this place sorta reminds me of something.

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: "It's a Wonderful Life."

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: The Jimmy Stewart picture?  I remember that one.  Saw it over at the Bijou.  So, you remember that, huh?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: "It's a Wonderful Life?"

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: Or the Bijou.  Either one.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I remember the picture... but I don't remember where I saw it.

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: C'mon, I'll give you two a lift back to the Bijou.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: The Bijou?

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: Well, no, but these gentlemen would like to get some answers...

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I don't know what else to tell you. I wasn't hiding out.  I hit my head and I didn't remember anything until a few days ago.

turns.speaker: FITTS
turns.text: Luke, you probably don't remember me, Roscoe Fitts, I'm the grocer here in town.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Good to meet you.  Again.

turns.speaker: FITTS
turns.text: Like Ernie said, we're all glad to have you back.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: FITTS
turns.text: And I hear you and Harry are planning on re-opening the Bijou.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: We're gonna try.  Place needs a lot of work.

turns.speaker: FITTS
turns.text: I can only imagine.  You know, I spoke with your Dad last year about maybe taking the Bijou off his hands.  I don't think he gave it very much thought.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Well, he loves the place.  It's his home.

turns.speaker: FITTS
turns.text: Luke, I'm hopping you can help him see the reality of the situation. I'll come to the point.  I want to buy the property, and I'm prepared to offer six-thousand dollars for it.  And that's just for the property, mind you.  If you want, I'll leave it to you and your father to dismantle and liquidate the building for whatever salvage value it has, and you keep those proceeds.  I just want the land.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: That's... well, that's very generous, but if you've already got a store...?

turns.speaker: FITTS
turns.text: The days of the storefront grocery are numbered.  I plan on putting up a free-standing supermarket.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: A super market.  Huh.

turns.speaker: FITTS
turns.text: You think it over.  No reason to risk financial ruin for the sake of a crumbling old building.

turns.speaker: FITTS
turns.text: So... you do intend to fix the place up after all?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Mr. Fitts, with all due respect, I think Lawson needs the Bijou a bit more than it needs a super market. And I think Lawson deserves the Bijou.  There's not a lot that can be done to help us get past the pain we've all felt...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Excuse me... what's your, um, your name?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Harry, son.  Harry.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: And... what's my name again?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Albert Lucas Trumbo.  But you've been "Luke" since you were a baby.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Ah.  Luke.  Luke.  I like it.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You never came back from the war. We were told you were missing and presumed dead.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: When did I leave?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You joined up one month to the day after Pearl Harbor.  January seventh... nineteen forty-two.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Nine and-a-half years ago.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Nine and-a-half years...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Wait'll you see the inside!

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Can't wait.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: We've been closed for a while.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Ah.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Exactly how long has the Bijou been closed?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Hmmmm... after you left, it was difficult, and then Lily -- that's your mother -- she took ill and died... we haven't shown a picture since forty-eight.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Well, after the war, with so many of the town's boys killed, people around here didn't much feel like going to the movies, I guess.  Some of 'em moved away -- Los Angeles, Sacramento, San Francisco.  Wasn't much to keep 'em here, I expect. And now with this "television" thing -- people just aren't going out as much as they used to.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Didn't you have any help?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh, I had Irene and Old Tim but they really couldn't help much. Broke their hearts when we closed up.  Broke mine, too.  But now that you're back, well, things will be different around here, that's for sure.  C'mon, I'll show you where we live.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: That's Lily.  Your mother, rest her soul.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Mother.  She's beautiful.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Well, yes, that she was.  She certainly made this place a home.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: They couldn't wait to see you.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Who... are they?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: This is the staff of the Bijou.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Oh.  What... what time is it?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Six-thirty.  I thought we'd get an early start.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I promised him a new uniform when we re-opened.  And you'll get one, too.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: You know, I hate to bring this up, but screens and uniforms and paint and repairs are going to take money, which I'm willing to bet none of us has.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Um... Harry?  Did I ever keep the books here?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: No, your mother did, then I did after she passed.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Well, I'm the first one to admit that I don't know anything about bookkeeping, but there are some very interesting things in here.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: "February 10, 1942.  Picture 'Ball of Fire.'"

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Gary Cooper.  And Barbara Stanwyck. Yowsa.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: "Eight p.m. showtime, ninety-six admissions, receipts including concessions, $84.75... plus one fryer and two-dozen eggs."

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: "one fryer and two-dozen eggs?"

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Forty-two was a lean year around here.  The war had just started... you were gone less than a month... and we were coming off a bit of a drought as I recall.  Not everyone could ante up the price of a ticket, and a chicken's as good as money if you ask me.  At that time, it meant a lot to the folks around here to be able to come to the pictures.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yeah, I know, but poultry...?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I know it's hard to believe, son, but this place, this little place this wasn't a theater then, this was a palace!  Any man, woman, child, you, me, it didn't matter, you bought your ticket and you walked in and you...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: But I...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Son, I think you loved the Bijou even more than I did.  You've got to remember that.  You've got to.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Ernie.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: ... Ernie.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Carl.  Friend of yours from high school.  Everybody calls him "Cueball."

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Oh, hi Cue... Carl.  Sorry.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I'll be home in a little while, Harry.  Don't wait up.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You two have a lot of catching up to do, I guess.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: You bet.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Goodnight, son.  'Night, Delly.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Between a new screen, paint, plumbing for the concession stand, and about a hundred other repairs around the theater... it's going to cost at least nine hundred dollars to get the Bijou into shape to open up.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: And you have sixty-eight dollars and thirty-seven cents in the bank. Your only source of income are my veteran's death benefit of forty dollars a month, to which you're no longer entitled since I'm alive, and these ten dollar a month cash deposits you make.  What are those?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: They're...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Why don't you two get out there and dance?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh, no, I...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Beautiful, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Well, son, I wish I could've shown you more, but this is all that's left.  Just this one reel that never got sent back from a picture we showed here a long time ago. Nineteen twenty-five, to be exact...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Dad, I...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Ha!

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: ... what?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You know, since you've been back, that's the first time you've called me "Dad."

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Luke... what time is it?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Six-thirty.  I thought we'd get an early start.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Jesus...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: The film broke...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I know, I know... keep still.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I'm here.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Did you... did you...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Did I what?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Did you fix the damn film?  It broke in the last reel.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I know.  Everyone went home.  We offered them refunds.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Anybody take it?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: A few.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Vultures...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I'm not happy about this, mind you, but if I have to go, at least I'm going in my own bed, the same bed my Lily died in, and... knowing that my son is alive.  That's not too shabby, is it?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: You're not going anywhere, Harry.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Don't tell me, I know about these things.  I've seen it before.  It's all right.  It's... all right. You're here.  Oh, God, I love you, son.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Pete.  You think maybe you've had enough?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Bought the bottle, didn't I?  To the United States of America. Long my she wave.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Thanks, Jerry.  Tell me something.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: You tight with J. Edgar Hoover?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: The G-man?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Zackly.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Pete, if J. Edgar Hoover walked in here wearing a dress, I wouldn't know him.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Too bad.  He says I'm a communist.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You should watch what you say.  You don't know who's listening.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: You know I'm not a communist, don't you, Jer?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Sure, I suppose.  That why you're on a bender?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: This is not a bender yet.  This is the start of a bender.  But I can see how you were confused, they look a lot alike.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Pete... go home.  Come on, I'll call that girlfriend of yours, what's her name... Sandy?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Sandra Sinclair.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Gimmee her number, I'll have her pick you up.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Sandra Sinclair.  Wanna know her real name?  Bella Iskowitz.  No one's who they really are, Jer. Everyone's someone else.  Even you. Even me.  Especially me.  I'm Peter Appleton, the communist who's not really a communist.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I wanna close up soon.  C'mon, let's call her.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Nope.  Can't.  We're through.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Then I'll call you a cab.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I'll save you the trouble.  I'm a cab.  There.  Did it myself.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: 'Sides, car's right outside.  I'll be seein' ya, Jer.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Pete...

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Any idea how you got here, son?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Been drinkin' a bit, have we?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I don't remember.  I guess so. Smells like it.  Tastes like it.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Well, you've been wet to the skin. You must've fallen in.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I guess I did.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Lucky you got out, that water's got quite a pull, and it empties straight into the ocean.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Here, one of mine.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Do you remember if you were driving a car?  Maybe you went over the bridge.  No guard rail there, it's easy to do.  It's happened before.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: It's possible.  I just don't remember.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: And you don't know your name or who you are, that right?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I... no, I... I just can't...

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: It's okay, son.  We just need to call you something.  That's all.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Call me... Ishmael?

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Well, at least you remember "Moby Dick."

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: That's me and my daughter Adele. My pride and joy.  Charms the fish right out of the lake, she does.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: She's very pretty.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Thanks.  Well, Sheriff's on his way over, and maybe we can get to the bottom of who you are...

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: ... sorry 'bout that, but you do look familiar to me.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Wish I could say the same thing.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: That's where you live.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: We live in a theater?

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Evening, Luke.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Evening, Doctor Lardner.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Uh, no... just seeing you standing there, it reminded me... there's a word for it...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Oh, you mean the suit.  Harry kept all my old clothes.  Fits okay, but it's a little big.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: You kids off to the dance?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Aren't you coming?

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: No, I'm not much of a dancer.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: It's a pretty massive heart attack. His lungs have filled with fluid, and, well... it seems as though his body is just... shutting down.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Can we get him to the hospital?

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Even if we could, and the move didn't kill him, there'd be very little we could do there that we can't do here.  I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: You smell gas?

turns.speaker: SUPER
turns.text: Don't smell nothin'.  He must not be dead in here.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: SUPER
turns.text: Hey, it's the best way to tell.

turns.speaker: SUPER
turns.text: You think he's drunk somewhere?

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Wouldn't blame him if he was.

turns.speaker: SUPER
turns.text: Well, his rent's past due and he said to call you in case of an emergency.  He lose his job or somethin'?

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: What's his rent?

turns.speaker: SUPER
turns.text: Thirty a month.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Here's three months rent, and a ten spot for no more questions and to keep an eye on his place.  Now, I need a moment alone.

turns.speaker: SUPER
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Take a hike.  Am-scray.

turns.speaker: SUPER
turns.text: Huh?  Oh, sure.  Just pull the door shut when you leave.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Peter, their hands are tied.  You see that, don't you?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I... I don't believe this.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Are you saying it's a mistake, that you didn't go to any meetings? They say you did.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Who the hell is this "they?"

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Congress, the FBI, Red Channels, it don't matter who the hell "they" is.  "They" know who "they" are, that's all that matters.  Now, did you go to any meetings?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: No.  Yeah... I... I don't know. Maybe I did.  Leo, this was before Pearl Harbor.  I was in college. It was a bunch of kids, and I was just one of 'em.  I didn't believe in what they were saying.  Hell, I didn't even know what they were saying!

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: So, you're saying that it's true. You went to a meeting of a known communist organization.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Leo, I was trying to impress a skirt.  You know me, I'm non- political.  Republican, Democrat, Communist, there's not a dime's worth of difference between 'em anyway.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: You should watch what you say.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I don't know who fingered me, but I'm not a communist!

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Kid, that cuts no ice with them.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: What?  That I'm accused of being a communist when I don't happen to be one?

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: They know you were at that meeting, Peter.  They've been told, and they know.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Leo, you're my agent.  Tell "them" to take a flyin' piss.  I didn't do anything wrong.  I fought in the war, for crissakes!

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Fought?  Come on, Pete, you ran the PX at Fort Dix.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I was decorated.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: I know.  A Purple Heart.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Exactly.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: You broke your arm.  You were coming out of a bar.  You were drunk.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: At least I was on our side!  Look, they want me to testify?  I'll testify.  I'll tell 'em anything they want to hear!  Jesus, Leo, this is my career!

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: You can't testify.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: They don't want you to testify because you're not a big enough fish for them.  They just don't want you writing pictures for now. That's all.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Yeah, well, that's enough.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Peter, I believe in you.  More to the point, I read your new script... um...

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: "Ashes To Ashes?"

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: That's the one, "Ashes To Ashes." I think it's great.  But it'll never get made with this communist business hanging over your head. You can't work until you're cleared -- and believe me, starting right now, I'm gonna do everything I can to make that happen.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: So, it is a blacklist.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Don't say that.  There is no such thing as a blacklist.  Now, are you gonna play ball?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Yes.  Leo, goddammit... this isn't fair!

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: The FBI can't arrest you, because you haven't done anything wrong.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Well, that's a relief.  I understand they usually don't let that stop them.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: However... you're gonna be subpoenaed to testify before the Un-American Activities Committee when they open hearings in Los Angeles.  Now, if you play ball and tell them what they want to hear, they'll clear you.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: And I won't be a communist anymore.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Exactly.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: So it doesn't make any difference that I'm not one now, and have never been one.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Next time, it might be the FBI. The time after that, it might be the President.  But it'll always be someone.  Count on it.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: That's not the country Luke fought for.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Lest we forget, Peter, your own military career was somewhat less illustrious than Luke's.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: It's wrong, Leo.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Peter, don't let that stop you all of a sudden.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: That was quite a show you gave them today.  We shoulda sold tickets.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I'm not sorry for what I said.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: No, of course not, why should you be sorry?  You're the new Peter Appleton.  You exercised your rights as a solid citizen, first amendment, freedom of speech, all that.  Very noble.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Cigarette?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: No thanks.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: When'd you quit smoking?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Luke didn't smoke.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Oh, I see.  But you're not Luke. You're Peter Appleton, the picture writer.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Not any more.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Leo, you were in there, you saw what I did.  You think they're gonna let me write pictures?  Hell, they're probably gonna throw my ass in jail.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Besides, I don't even know if I want to write anymore.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: What, you're going to go back to that hick town and run the projector and marry the doctor's daughter?

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Peter, I'm an agent.  I buy lunches and get deals made for guys like you.  That's what I do.  You're a writer.  You write pictures. That's what you do.  And trust me, you'll be back doing it again tomorrow morning.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Kid, you gave them what they wanted.  This committee, it feeds on names.  The more names, the better.  But for some high-profile witnesses, like yourself, any name will do.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Leo, I didn't give them the names. I wouldn't do that.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: What, all of a sudden, "Lucille Angstrom" isn't a name?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Her name was right there in front of them.  They gave it to me, I didn't give it to them.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Well, that's not what they think.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Leo, she was... she was a girl I knew in college...

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: You should keep track of your old school chums.  Turns out she eventually joined the communist party.  On top of which, she's Lucy Angstrom Hirschfeld now, and she happens to be a writer for "Studio One" on CBS.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Oh god, oh, god, no, I...

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: So, our lawyers had a talk with the Committee's lawyers.  That Elvin Clyde fella won't be too happy about it, but we cut a deal. They cleared you -- and they're gonna thank you publicly for your testimony purging yourself.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Thank me publicly?  For what?  For ruining this woman's life?

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Climb down off your cross.  They already knew about her.  She was subpoenaed six months ago! Who the hell do you think named you?

turns.speaker: MRS. TERWILLIGER
turns.text: I haven't danced with another man since Mr. Terwilliger passed.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: When was that?

turns.speaker: MRS. TERWILLIGER
turns.text: Nineteen-oh-nine.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: That was beautiful.

turns.speaker: MRS. TERWILLIGER
turns.text: I taught you that.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I can play the piano?

turns.speaker: MRS. TERWILLIGER
turns.text: Oh dear, yes.  You were an excellent student, before all that clarinet nonsense.  You loved Chopin.  You used to call it "heaven music."  "Teach me some heaven music," you used to say.

turns.speaker: MRS. TERWILLIGER
turns.text: Sit.  Play with me.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: No, I...

turns.speaker: MRS. TERWILLIGER
turns.text: Some of it might come back to you.

turns.speaker: MRS. TERWILLIGER
turns.text: Luke!  Luke, something's wrong! The film broke, and I can't raise Harry on the house phone!

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MRS. TERWILLIGER
turns.text: You've got to talk to them before they tear the theater apart!

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Is there a young Tim?

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Well, then, why do they call you "Old Tim?"

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: Found me.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yeah.  I hope you don't mind.  I didn't know anyone lived here... well, besides Harry.  And me.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: So I guess this fellow belongs to you.  What's his name?

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: Cat.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Cat.  That's simple.  I like it.  Hi, Cat.

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: We thought you was dead, you know.  It's okay that I live here?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: T-t-thank you.  Thank you.  I... I always... I always wanted to wear my uniform from the Great War, but your daddy, he always said no, that's not an usher's u-u-uniform, that's an army uniform and the Bijou, she's not the army.  They give me a medal, but I lost it in the h-h-hospital.  I forget things sometimes.  Since the w-w-war.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yeah... me too.

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: That's my r-r-rent.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: Can I... Can I t-t-talk to you?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Sure.  Come on in.  I was just packing.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Please, sit.

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: They'll come back, you know. They'll all c-c-come back.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: The customers?  I don't know...

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: They will.  They w-w-will.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Tim, I have to tell you something.

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: It's about me.

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I'm... I'm not Luke.  Luke is dead. He died in the war.  He's not coming back, and I'm not him.  I don't even belong here.  This whole thing started out as an accident, and that's all it is.  An accident.

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: Oh...

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: My name isn't Luke.  It's Peter. Peter Appleton.

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: Did you think I didn't kn-kn-know that?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I thought you...

turns.speaker: OLD TIM
turns.text: I know more than you give me c-c- credit, that's for sure.  Don't you see, it don't m-m-matter who you are?  All that matters is what you g-g-gave us.  And you can't take that away now.  You're wrong, Peter Appleton.  You do belong here.

turns.speaker: SANDRA
turns.text: Pete, there's time before the picture starts, you want to get some popcorn?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: You bet, honey.

turns.speaker: SANDRA
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: What exactly did you hear?

turns.speaker: SANDRA
turns.text: That you got let go.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I wasn't alone.  Wasn't Frankie Ruskin directing the picture you're in?

turns.speaker: SANDRA
turns.text: He was, but he got sick.  We got a new director today.  Why?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Well, whatever Frankie's got, it's catching.

turns.speaker: SANDRA
turns.text: You mean, he was... let go, too?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: They're saying I'm a communist, Sandy.  But I'm not, you know that. I'm gonna fight 'em, and I'm gonna win, but I'll need your help.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Will you help me, Sandy?

turns.speaker: SANDRA
turns.text: I'll have to think about this.  I have to get back... I should go...

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Ancestors?

turns.speaker: STANTON
turns.text: Actually, my grandpap.  But "ancestors" sounds better, don't it?  Here.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I suppose.  Thanks.

turns.speaker: STANTON
turns.text: You look familiar, fella.  What's your name?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: They all know you?

turns.speaker: STANTON
turns.text: 'Course they all know me.  And I know all them.  Town's got my name, don't it?

turns.speaker: STANTON
turns.text: Ernie Cole here just got himself elected mayor.  Lost both his boys in the war.  Kenny at Anzio and Willie at Normandy.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: The war...

turns.speaker: STANTON
turns.text: Mabel over there at the diner lost her husband Max.  Okinawa, I believe.

turns.speaker: STANTON
turns.text: You hungry, son?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Yes.  Very.

turns.speaker: STANTON
turns.text: Got any money?

turns.speaker: STANTON
turns.text: Said as much myself, Doc.  Can't place him, though.  To look at him, you'd think the cheese slid off his cracker.  Well, morning's half-over.  I'm off.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Thank you, Mr. Lawson.

turns.speaker: STANTON
turns.text: Don't mention it.  Whoever-you-are.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Now that you remember who you are, were you planning on telling anyone your true identity?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I already have.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: My girlfriend.  If she still is...

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Would that be Miss Sinclair?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: No.  No, not Miss Sinclair.  I'm talking about Adele Lardner.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Mr. Appleton, I have reason to believe you're holding something back, and that just rubs me the wrong way.  Sir, are you a communist?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: No.  Absolutely not.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: All right.  All right.  We'll see.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Miss Hayworth?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I'm Melanie Daniels. I'm sorry to bother you, but...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: The man at the post office sent me. He said you'd know the name of the little Brenner girl.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Cathy?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: The one who lives in the white house across the bay?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's the one. Cathy Brenner.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: They seemed sure it was either Alice or Lois.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Which is why the mail in this town never gets delivered to the right place.  Did you want to see Cathy about something?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Are you a friend of Mitch's?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No, not really.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I've been wanting a cigarette for the past twenty minutes, but I couldn't convince myself to stop. This 'tilling of the soil' can get a little compulsive, you know.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: It's a lovely garden.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Thank you. It gives me something to do with my spare time.  There's a lot of spare time in Bodega Bay.  Did you plan on staying long?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No. Just a few hours.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You're leaving after you see Cathy?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Well... something like that.  I'm sorry. I don't mean to sound so mysterious.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Actually, it's none of my business.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Did you drive up from San Francisco?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's a nice drive.  Is that where you met Mitch?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I guess that's where everyone meets him.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Do I?  No, I'm an open book, I'm afraid.  Or maybe a closed one.  Pretty. What are they?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Lovebirds.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Mmm.  Well, good luck, Miss Daniels.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, hi!  Did you find her all right?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes, I did.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I was wondering...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: That sign.  Do you think I could have the room for a single night?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I'd really hope to rent it for...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I would appreciate it. I've tried everywhere in town, and they're all full.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Sure. You can have it.  Where's your bag? In the car?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's utilitarian, I'll say that for it.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I just picked up some things for the night at the general store. You see, I hadn't planned on spending much time here.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yes, I know. Did something unexpected crop up?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Miss Daniels? Is that you?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Hi.  Is something wrong? Is that cut beginning to bother you?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No, it's not the cut that's bothering me.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Would you like some brandy?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: If you have some, I'd...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'll get it, sit down, Miss Daniels. Do you want a sweater or something? A quilt?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No, thank you.  Won't you call me Melanie?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: All right.
